description: This is a specimen of the conductor, together with a model of the dial used by Sir Francis Ronalds on the experimental electric telegraph circuit in the garden of his house in the Upper Mall, Hammersmith, in 1816. He employed a frictional electric machine (see Cat. No. 3) to charge the line, and at each end had a pith-ball electroscope which collapsed when the line was discharged. At the two stations were dials revolved synchronously by clockwork; the dials were marked with the alphabet, but were masked by front plates that left only one letter visible. The sender discharged the line when he saw the desired letter, and the receiver noted the letter at which the pith-balls collapsed. By the use of a code, a word or even a whole sentence could be conveyed by two or three discharges. Ronalds made his first experiments through eight miles of overhead wire suspended by silk from hooks in horizontal bars. He then laid down his underground line :— “A trench was dug in the garden 525 ft. in length and 4 ft. deep ; in this was laid a trough of wood 2 in. sq., lining the inside of it with pitch, and in this trough tubes were placed through which the wires ran. The joints between the glass tubes were made with soft wax. The trough was then covered with pieces of wood screwed down upon it while the pitch was hot ; these also were well covered with pitch and the earth then thrown into the trench again.” Some of this line was dug up in 1862. The invention was brought to the notice of the Admiralty, but it was then deemed “wholly unnecessary,” and Ronalds seems to have gone no further with it.

object_name: COPY OF SCHILLING'S ELECTRIC TELEGRAPH. Plate I.
description: This is a copy of a portion of the telegraph, preserved in the Imperial Academy of Sciences, Petrograd, which was the outcome of experiments made by Baron P. L. Schilling in 1825–32. The receiver part of the instrument consists of a galvanometer with a horizontal needle suspended by a silken thread. The needle carries above it a disc of paper painted black on one side and white on the other; by the deflection of the needle to right or left, two primary signals were obtained. The instrument was made almost " dead beat " by a plate on the axis dipping into a bath of mercury beneath. The alarm call shown consists of a horizontal needle suspended in a coil and so arranged that when deflected by the passage of a current it strikes a trigger gear that releases the escapement of a clockwork alarm. The currents were first transmitted by placing the ends of the line wires in a bath of mercury, but afterwards a simple key was added.

description: TYPE USED FOR ORIGINAL MORSE TELEGRAPH. Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General. 1835 These are relics of the electric telegraph devised by Prof. S. B. Morse and constructed by him in 1835. The transmitter consisted of a clockwork mechanism by means of which cast metal type, some of which are shown, were fed past a lever. The serrations on the edges of the type actuated the lever and thereby caused it to make intermittent contact in a pair of mercury cups. In the receiver an electro-magnetic arrangement caused a pen to make irregular V-shaped marks on a paper strip which was drawn past it by clockwork. These marks were interpreted as numbers which were arranged in a code-book. A model of the apparatus was worked through ten miles of insulated wire, wound upon two reels, in the year 1837. Inv. 1894-158A.

object_name: SIR W. F. COOKE'S ORIGINAL ELECTRIC ALARUM
description: The alarum is set in motion by means of an electro-magnet. The armature on being actuated removes a detent and allows the clockwork to ring the bell. Finding that the alarum would not work reliably, through even one mile of wire, Sir W. F. Cooke consulted Sir Charles Wheatstone with a view to finding a remedy. This resulted in the invention of the Wheatstone relay, a delicate instrument, which by responding to feeble currents, closes a local battery circuit through the coils of the alarum electro-magnet, and permits of signalling over great distances. Developments of the relay are in use in nearly all modern telegraph systems. The first meeting of Wheatstone and Cooke took place in February, 1837, and led to the establishment of the partnership which extended over many years and proved so productive of new ideas in the progress of the electric telegraph.

The arrangement consists of a wooden block of trapezoidal section, in the top and two sides of which five copper wires were inserted, in grooves containing a resinous material, and blocked up with strips of wood, the whole being afterwards coated with a protecting compound.

description: This instrument was included in 1837 by Messrs. Cooke & Wheatstone in their first patent for improvements in giving signals by electric currents; a single-needle telegraph was, however, already known. Five galvanometers or magnetic needles and coils were used, arranged in a horizontal row on the vertical diamond-shaped dial; stops were placed to limit the deflection of the needles. Each needle was operated by a separate lever fitted with two finger keys, so arranged that a current could be sent in either direction. When signalling two needles were simultaneously deflected in opposite directions, the letter was indicated by the intersection of their centre lines on the dial and the point of intersection of their centre lines on the dial indicated the letter to be read off. Twenty letters could thus be signalled, and by employing the needles singly the ten numerals could be transmitted; these numerals were placed on the margins of the lower half of the dial. To obtain a closed circuit when the needles were used singly, a sixth lever and line wire were provided. The letters C, J, Q, U, X, and Z were not represented on the dial, other letters or combinations of letters being used instead. Plate 2.

description: Lent by Messrs. Reid Bros. 1837 This is one of Messrs. Cooke & Wheatstone's instruments of 1837 which was used on the line between Paddington and Slough in 1842. In 1845 it created much interest through having secured the capture of a murderer. Owing to the frequent failure of one of the line wires, or of four or five-needle instruments, it was soon found by the operators that the alphabet could be formed by two needles only, if advantage were taken of repeated momentary deflections. The coils and needles are similar to those of the five-needle instrument, but the code was different, since the symbols were indicated by deflections of one or both of the needles; two line wires were used. An alarm which could be cut out by means of a handle at the side of the instrument was placed at the top. Plate 2. Inv. 1876-1275.

description: Lent by Messrs. Reid Bros. 1839 (designed by Sir W. F. Cooke); 1846 (patent). This is one of the first of this type of instrument, having been designed by Sir W. F. Cooke in 1839; similar ones were tried on the Great Western Railway between Paddington and Slough. The instrument was included in Messrs. Cooke & Wheatstone's patent of 1846. There is a spring-driven clockwork train which actuates the pointer, controlled by an escapement worked by pallets which are a continuation of a hinged armature vibrating between two electro-magnets. The current is generated by rotating the outer rim of the dial by means of a knob (broken off); the rim gear drives two pinions each provided with two discs insulated by ivory and pressed on by springs, forming a make-and-break contact, but the machine is incomplete. Inv. 1876-1418.

description: SPECIMEN OF EARLY UNDERGROUND TELEGRAPH CABLE LAID IN LONDON, 1846. Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General. 1846. description: This system, which requires no battery for its operation, was patented in 1848 by Messrs. W. F. Henley & T. Forster. It was used in this country by the Magnetic Telegraph Company. When one of the two pedal keys is depressed, an electro-magnet is partially rotated in close proximity to the poles of a powerful compound permanent magnet. This movement generates a momentary magneto-electric current which passes to line and operates the corresponding needle at both the sending and receiving stations. On releasing the key, it is restored to its former position by a strong spring, and by this reversed movement, another momentary current is transmitted, this time in a contrary direction. On the axis of each indicating needle, and parallel to it is a small permanent magnet which swings between the poles of a semicircular electro-magnet. The pulsation of current received from line causes the electro-magnet to deflect the permanent magnet, and the deflection is continued by the effect of the induced magnetism between the two. Each needle can only be deflected to one side of the vertical position, the motion being limited by two stops.

description: This instrument was used about 1853 by the Electric Telegraph Co. It supplanted Bain's chemical recorder, as it obviated the troublesome chemical preparation of the paper, but reading the embossed marks was found so fatiguing, that this instrument was in turn displaced by the ink-writer. A relay or local circuit is used to work the electro-magnet, whose armature is fitted to a horizontal lever, working between stops at one end and carrying a steel style at the other. When the armature is attracted downwards, the style is pressed upwards against a strip of paper drawn from a large reel by two friction rollers, set in motion by a train of clockwork. In the upper roller is a narrow groove into which the style presses the paper and, according to the time the armature is held down, embosses a dot or a dash.

description: This instrument was adopted by the British Post Office in 1874, but had previously been in use in America. It consists of an electro-magnet having a soft iron armature mounted on a lever which moves between stops. The armature is attracted on the passage of the current, in opposition to the pull of a spring, and each signal consists of two clicks, one as the armature descends when attracted and the other when it returns under the action of the spring, the interval between the two depending upon whether the signal is a dot or a dash.

description: Wheatstone Collection. 1858 This instrument is described in Sir C. Wheatstone's patent No. 1241, of 1858, where it is claimed that it works with "currents of less energy" and "with greater steadiness, certainty, and rapidity" than previous instruments. The dial has symbols corresponding with the instrument with which it works. The pointer is fixed on a small escape-wheel of 15 teeth which is propelled by a hair-spring; the levers are attached to two small magnets fixed to an arbor vibrating between the pole pieces of two small electro-magnets. A button above the dial serves to adjust the pointer by hand, and in the lower part of the case is placed an alarm.

description: Made by Messrs. Siemens Bros. Lent by H.M. Postmaster-General. 1862 This instrument, made by Messrs. Siemens Bros., embodies their patent of 1862; it superseded the Morse embosser, owing to its sensitiveness to weak currents, and to the greater legibility of the marks made. It has in turn been superseded by various type-printing telegraphs. The form shown is supplied with a signalling key and galvanometer, and was used on lines of moderate length where a relay was not required. The armature of the electro-magnet is attached to a hinged lever working between stops; when no current is passing, it is brought to the upper position by a spring. A plain disc, fixed to a continuation of the hinged lever, lies behind the paper tape, from a horizontal reel contained in a drawer in the base of the instrument, is carried between friction rollers worked by a clock-train controlled by a governor, the train also revolving the inking disc. When the armature is attracted the inking disc is thrown into contact with the paper strip, and, according to the duration of the current, registers a dot or dash. All the parts can be regulated by screw adjustments. Inv. 1876-1291.

description: This was the earliest form of acoustic instrument introduced into Great Britain, where it was used by the British and Irish Magnetic Telegraph Co. Two plates or bells of different tones are used to produce a code by means of sound. The hammers are fixed to the armatures of two electro-magnets, the relay which works being pivoted on a magnetised rod enclosed in a coil. The coils consists of two thin permanent magnets placed side by side, their poles being furnished with pole pieces turning inwards. Between these vibrate the ends of two slightly magnetised levers pivoted on vertical axes, the poles of the magnets being so placed that a current in one direction attracts a magnet which closes the local circuit of the right-hand bell and the current in the opposite direction attracts the other magnet which closes the local circuit of the left-hand bell. The pedal or tapper-key is used to send the signals.

Developments of the Neale sounder are shown in adjacent positions. The sending portion of the apparatus consists of a double tapper commutator, similar to that used for single-needle instruments. description: This instrument is a later development of the original pattern of Neale's Sounder. The electrical part of the apparatus consists of an electro-magnet, with extensions of its soft-iron pole-pieces brought through the dial. Between the pole-pieces is a pivoted piece of thick soft iron, the upper part of which is rendered magnetic by induction from an angular permanent magnet, placed behind the dial. The sounder strikes with stiff wire extensions, projecting horizontally, upon which the needle strikes. The milled screw below the dial is for the purpose of adjusting the needle to the central position. The instrument has been partially sectioned to show the arrangement of the permanent and electro-magnets.

description: This compact telegraph set enables the sender to take a carbon copy of the transmitted message from the signals actually sent. The style is a single current Morse key and when held as a pencil, with the white stud uppermost, pressure of the point on the paper closes a circuit connecting the battery to line. In practice, therefore, the message is written and signalled at the same time in Morse code. When not in use for sending, the style joins the line to one end of an electro-magnet coil, the other end of which is connected to earth. The coil works on a pivoted arm and is lightly held against a limiting stop by a spiral spring. When a current passes through the windings, the coil turns downward on its pivots and the metal ends of the core strike on an iron plate, thus giving the characteristic click of a sounder. A small compass needle, supported near the coil, acts as a galvanometer by electro-magnetic induction.

description: invented during the war of 1914–18. This instrument, which was invented by Major A. C. Fuller, R.E., was extensively used during the war of 1914–18. Under ideal conditions, the apparatus is so sensitive that it will operate with a current of less than half a micro-ampere. On field lines, where heavy leakage is frequently experienced, the system is superior to other methods of line telegraphy. It possesses the outstanding advantage that the weak direct current traversing the circuit does not produce noticeable inductive effects in adjacent wires and it is almost impossible for a Fullerphone circuit to be “tapped.” At the receiving station the signals are passed through an interrupter which renders them suitable for reception on a telephone receiver. The Fullerphone may also be superposed on telephone circuits so that both telegraph and telephone services work simultaneously without the one interfering with the other.

It possesses the outstanding advantage that the weak direct current traversing the circuit does not produce noticeable inductive effects in adjacent wires and it is almost impossible for a Fullerphone circuit to be “tapped.” At the receiving station the signals are passed through an interrupter which renders them suitable for reception on a telephone receiver. The Fullerphone may also be superposed on telephone circuits so that both telegraph and telephone services work simultaneously without the one interfering with the other.

description: This receiver was used by the Electric Telegraph Co. (1850) to replace the double-needle instrument. It is now only in use for experimental purposes, but is so rapid and sensitive in its action that it may again come into favour. A strip of paper is drawn off a small gutta-percha bobbin placed inside a short brass cylinder, and over a drum whose surface is silvered; the latter is rotated by a clockwork train having a fan brake. The clockwork is started or stopped by a small lever working between two stops and when in the stopping position makes contact with the earth terminal. A small wooden roller is pushed into contact with the silvered drum to keep the paper stretched and against which it is kept pressed down to the paper. The style (missing) is a piece of iron or steel and is in connection with the line wire terminal, while the drum is in connection with the earth terminal. The paper tape was soaked in a mixture of one volume of a saturated solution of potassium ferrocyanide, one volume of a saturated solution of ammonium nitrate, and two volumes of water; the latter salt, being deliquescent, served to keep the paper damp. When a current passes, the iron decomposes the electrolyte, uniting the acid radical to form Prussian blue; other solutions, such as potassium iodide, can be used, the iodine liberated from which colours a starch solution. The Steilheil code, (dots in two parallel lines) was originally used but was entirely superseded by the Morse.

description: This telegraph was patented by Mr. Jacob Brett in 1845, as a communication from Mr. R. E. House, of New York. The instruments shown are those by which the first messages through the submarine cable from Dover to Cape Gris Nez were transmitted, in 1851. The transmitter has 40 buttons or keys, but there are only 29 different symbols, as the commoner ones are repeated. The keys are in two straight lines and when depressed engage with pins disposed in a single helix on the surface of a cylinder, rotated by bevel friction wheels, controlled by a continuously running fly. Fixed to the end of the cylinder is a commutator pressing upon two straight lines in the line circuit by which intermittent currents are sent to line when the wheel is released, the cylinder starts revolving at its full speed. In the receiver is a type-wheel, with the same number of symbols in the same order as in the transmitter, rotated by spring-driven wheelwork. A flier arm on the axis of the type-wheel engages with a tooth on the armature lever of an electro-magnet attracted by the intermittent currents. The type-wheel is further controlled by a ratchet wheel, the pawl of which can only move slowly, being attached to a dash-pot. The paper tape is advanced by a separate train of wheels which also give motion, whenever the type-wheel stops, to a pad wheel. The paper tape is advanced by eccentrics which move the plate up to the type. Inking is done by a roller. A call alarm is struck at every revolution on the eccentrics, but is secured by a hook when the instrument is in use.

description: This instrument was invented by Prof. D. E. Hughes in 1855, for recording in roman type the message transmitted. It is much used on the Continent, but did not at first meet with such favour in this country, on account of its cost. The instrument differs from the other type-printers in being almost entirely mechanical; both sender and transmitter are identical in construction and action of the printing signals, synchronism being secured by the correcting action of the printing signals. On a piano keyboard are 26 keys, each with two symbols on it, which correspond with raised type on the periphery of the type-wheel; there are also two blank-space and change-case keys. When a key is depressed, one of the pins on the circumference of a circular plate is raised and catches a “chariot” geared with the type-wheel so closing the circuit. The gearing is so arranged that when the type-wheel is stopped by the pin the symbol corresponding to the key is opposite to the printing hammer. The current causes the paper at both stations to be lifted up into contact with the type, and at the same time an electro-magnet releases the detent in the gearing which drives the hammer. The gearing also causes the paper to move forward a space to be ready for the next symbol. The electrical arrangement is very simple; the current which is sent so weakens the polarity of an induced magnet as to cause it to release an armature under spring pressure; the armature is replaced by a cam. The instrument is sensitive to very weak currents, owing to the close balance that can be secured by adjusting the spring.

description: Automatic transmitters are instruments for sending into a line wire by mechanical means the irregular sequence of currents representing a message. Several operators may be employed preparing the messages for the transmitter, which then forwards them at a speed which is restricted only by the mechanical limits of the receiving instrument. The instruments, which are fully described in Sir C. Wheatstone's patent No. 1239, A.D. 1858, are intended to transmit currents from a battery. In the first two, a handle, driven by spur gearing, drives a fly-wheel and a crank which reciprocates a small frame, through which passes a tape having the message on it as a series of holes punched by a perforating instrument. On this frame is a spring clip which holds the paper during one swing of the frame but is raised during the return movement. There are three wires on the reciprocating frame, held up by light helical springs so that a slight and pressure is capable of keeping them depressed. "The middle wire only acts as a guide to the paper during the cessation of the currents," while the two outside wires are provided with contact-makers, by which a current is sent to line in one direction when one wire is elevated and in the opposite direction by the other. The third instrument closely resembles these but is intended for transmitting unreversed currents only.

description: This instrument is designed for perforating the strip of paper or "tape," used in automatic transmitters. The first puncher, by Sir C. Wheatstone (patent No. 1239, A.D. 1858) perforated the tape in two parallel lines representing the signals, while a central line of holes indicated the spaces between letters and words. The code used was a modification of Steinheil’s (1836), in which the number of holes in succession on either side of the central line was limited to four. In this instrument, patented by Sir C. Wheatstone in 1867, the tape is punched with a uniform line of central apertures, the signals as before being indicated by side perforations. There are three keys fixed to bell-crank levers, lifted by springs and each controlling a punch. The tape from a reel is drawn down a vertical groove by means of a small disc and lever worked from the central key-lever. The outside key-levers punch the side holes representing the symbols and by a projection on the centre key depressed it also. The latter is depressed independently for the spaces between letters and words.

description: These are step-by-step instruments, patented by Mr. M. Theiler in 1861, and the transmitter resembles Wheatstone’s later A B C instruments, and has 28 keys arranged round a circular horizontal dial. The end of each key lever enters a circular ring provided with inclined notches; when a key is depressed it is kept down by the ring, but when a second key is touched that ring is slightly moved, so releasing the other key and locking the second one. Depressing a key also releases a wheel on a spring-driven train, which allows the pointer to travel round till stopped by the key lever; the axis of the pointer carries a commutator which sends to the line wire a reversed current for every letter that the pointer passes. In the receiver a type-wheel, on the axis of an escapement actuated by a spring-driven drum wound up by the printing mechanism, is controlled by spring-driven currents. Printing is performed by a spring-driven train liberated by an electro-magnet on a local battery circuit, closed by a vibratory arrangement which acts when the type-wheel stops.

This is a modification of the telegraph patented in 1863-4 by Mons. P. A. J. Dujardin; the instrument was used by the Electric Telegraph Co. during 1865 on the line between London and Edinburgh. The receiver and transmitter are identical. There is a piano keyboard of 28 keys, each of which by a lever raises a pin in the periphery of a circular plate and catches an arm kept revolving by the treadle-wheel below. On the same shaft is a 14-wave face cam which causes a lever to vibrate between stops and sends reversals of the current to line to release the escapement of the type-wheel step by step. A polarised relay and local battery are used to work the wheelwork and prolong the action on the anchor at the extremity of any particular oscillation; this closes the local circuit of an electro-magnet which does the printing. An electro-magnetic device causes the printing currents to be equal in duration whether a key is held down for a long or a short interval of time. Inking is done by a pad.

description: This perforator is described in Sir C. Wheatstone’s patent of 1867. It has three keys with rubber buffers, which are struck by small hand stamps, held one in each hand, so that the work of punching is done by the arms instead of by the fingers. There are five punches so arranged that the right-hand key punches three holes, the left-hand key three holes, while the central key punches a single hole. The paper is fed through by a roller and a roughened lever, which is moved when any of the three key levers is depressed.

description: This instrument, patented in this country in 1872 by Mr. Edison, is for printing in roman characters on paper tape; it was originally intended for transmitting stock exchange prices, a large number of these receivers being actuated simultaneously by currents from one central transmitter. The receiver shown is the original apparatus, but is incomplete. The instrument is mounted on a hollow cast-iron base which contains two horse-shoe electro-magnets, one of which vibrates a lever that presses the tape upon the type-wheel, and at the same time feeds it through the machine; the other magnet vibrates a lever which carries a pawl that rotates the type-wheel by a step-by-step motion. The roll of tape is supported by arms above the instrument and the inking of the type is performed by a roller. By the use of polarised armatures, a single wire with reversed currents works the two electro-magnets as required. Inv.

description: This important system was invented by J. M. E. Baudot, a French Telegraph Engineer, in 1874-5. Only the receiver is shown. The Baudot multiplex is extensively used in this country, being worked under simplex conditions designed by Mr. A. C. Booth, of the Post Office Engineering Department, in 1905. By this method, it is not unusual for 8, 10 or even 12 telegrams to be in process of transmission over a single circuit at the same time. The type wheel is kept constantly revolving, a small electric motor being externally fitted for the purpose. The five relays at the top of the apparatus select the symbol to be printed, in accordance with the signals sent from the distant station. By mechanical means, the paper tape is flicked into contact with the type-wheel immediately the required character is in position for printing.

description: This is a modern sending plate, of French pattern, designed for use on a Baudot quadruple telegraph set. Revolving brushes of flexible metal sweep over the surfaces of the rings in pairs. For instance, the second ring, consisting of 24 segments, may be joined through a pair of brushes to the continuous ring number 5, which is connected to line. In this way each keyboard is in contact with the line for a fraction of a second at frequent intervals. A separate distributor plate, of slightly different construction, is required for receiving. All the brushes are, however, carried on a common spindle which passes through the central aperture of both plates.

description: The experimental transmitter and receiver are shown, together with specimens of the writing and a diagram of the general arrangement. The instruments were invented by Mr. E. A. Cowper in 1878, and have worked successfully through a resistance of 1,000 ohms. Two line wires are used, one of which transmits a current proportional to the vertical and the other to the horizontal displacement of the transmitter’s pen from its central position. This is accomplished by having attached to this pen two jointed rods which transmit the two components of the motion to contact pieces that slide over resistance frames arranged at right angles. These frames are built up of insulated plates set on edge and connected by a wire of high resistance. At the receiving end each wire circuit actuates its own needle, but the two needles are at right angles and provided with light springs by which they are connected with a single vertical capillary siphon or pen with its point in contact with a paper tape. The paper at both stations is drawn along continuously by clockwork contained in the bases of the instruments.

description:
A method of simultaneously sending a number of messages in either direction along one line wire, which necessitated synchronous movements of apparatus at the two stations, was suggested by Mr. B. Meyer in 1871 and was rendered practicable for Morse working by Mr. P. B. Delany in 1882–4.
The principle is indicated by a diagram in which A and B represent two stations connected by a line wire, and x, y are two arms, rotating at equal rates over the numbered segments which are insulated from one another. If each segment be connected with transmitting and receiving instruments any message transmitted from 1 will be received at 1', from 2 at 2', and so on.
A reed and wheel arrangement patented by Mr. P. la Cour in 1878 and invented, independently, by Lord Rayleigh, is employed to drive each arm at a rate of about three revolutions per sec. The reed is kept in a state of vibration by means of an electro-magnet, the movements of the reed itself producing the necessary makes and breaks of the circuit as in a trembling bell. Included in the circuit there is a second electro-magnet, which drives a phonic-wheel and is mounted on the axis of the rotating arm. The latter consequently moves at a rate determined by the vibrations of its reed. A fly-wheel mounted on the same axis, is made of wood containing mercury in two concentric grooves.
This arrangement does not, however, ensure absolute synchronism, and further provision is made by sending and receiving correction currents. When the arm at one station is over a sending-correction group, that at the other station is over a receiving-correction group.
The number of messages which can be sent simultaneously depends on the retardation of the line.
This system was, at one time, used in this country to a limited extent, hexode working being employed between London and Birmingham.
The apparatus exhibited consists of a distributor and a reed. To render the wheel visible, the distributor has been removed from the metal ring upon which it was mounted.

description: This step-by-step instrument was patented by Mr. W. S. Steljes in 1895–8, and has been extensively used on private lines. The communicator at the sending station is of the ordinary A B C type and has a shuttle-wound armature which transmits alternating currents. At the receiving station, these pass through the coils of an electro-magnet with a polarised armature, operating the escapement of a weight-driven train on wheels. This is connected with a type-wheel and the letter is then made to take up a position corresponding with the key depressed at the sending station. The currents also pass through a second electro-magnet, which is non-polarised and sufficiently sluggish in action to continue attracting its armature during the passage of the current. When the latter ceases, however, the armature is released and frees a second train of wheels driving an eccentric wheel, by means of a lever, raises a paper strip against the type-wheel and prints the letter signalled. The lever also operates a device for feeding forward the paper. The type-wheel is double, and consists of series of letters and figures side by side, the change from one set to the other being affected when the communicator key adjacent to “ letters ” or “ figures ” is depressed. In the example shown the arrangement for inking the type is missing.

description: In this telegraphic typewriter, which was patented by Mr. L. Kamm in 1895–1905, the printing is done in page form at both ends of the line by similar instruments, the operator at the transmitting end simply using a keyboard as in an ordinary typewriter. Two currents are sent over the line for each signal transmitted, the interval of time between the two depending upon the letter signalled. Mounted on a vertical axis, which carries a sector bearing the type, there is an arm, termed a “ synchronising arm,” which is normally retained in its zero position by a catch. When a key is depressed, this arm is released and a spring pin connected with the key lever is raised. At the same time, a current is sent over the line, which causes the arm at the receiving end also to be released. The arms receive motion from adjustable springs, and the arm at the transmitting station moves until arrested by the raised pin, contact with which sends a second current to line and brings the distant arm also to be brought to rest. This is effected by means of a piece on the underside of the arm, which, under the action of an electro-magnet, is made to project, and, as the arm moves at equal rates, to catch against the pin corresponding with the one raised at the sending station. A local circuit at each end is closed, which energises an electro-magnet and causes the type letter corresponding to the position of the arm to be printed on the paper. The arms are then returned to their initial positions by the action of other electro-magnets. For rotating the paper roller and returning the carriage to its initial position when commencing a new line, a separate electro-magnet is provided, the exciting circuit for which is closed when the arm moves over all the pins to its extreme position, a special key with no connected pin being provided for this purpose.

description: This apparatus was invented by F. G. Creed, Esq., about 1896, and is designed to produce perforations on Wheatstone slips at a high rate of speed with a minimum of labour. The telegraph operator, instead of having to build up Morse signals, by striking separate plungers for dots, dashes and spaces, as with the ordinary hand perforator, simply depresses a selected key, which punches the corresponding symbol complete. The instrument was used by the Post Office for about five years, and was then superseded by electrically worked keyboards which did not require a pneumatic supply.

description: Made and Presented by Donald Murray, Esq. In machine telegraphy an operator transmits messages by playing on a keyboard, and the whole of the rest of the work is done by machinery, the chief mechanism being the telegraph printer at the receiving station. The central principle in all such machines is that of the key and lock. There is a separate key and a separate lock for each letter. The keys are assembled in the transmitting keyboard, and the locks, which are at the receiving station, form a “selector” which operates the typewriter. In modern telegraph printers the permutation lever lock is used combined with what is known as the five-unit alphabet. As about 32 of these permutation lever locks are required for letters and operation signals, they are arranged in a circle or in a straight line. The circular form was the first to come into practical use in the type-writing telegraphs, culminating in the Baudot Multiplex in 1875. The straight-line plan was old, but was first put into practical form by Mr. Donald Murray in Sydney, Australia, in 1898, in the models which are here exhibited. The preliminary wooden model, which was made in 1896, shows the essential features of all subsequent machines of the straight-line class, including the Murray automatic printer adjacent to it. This printer was taken to New York in 1901, and was developed with the assistance of the Postal Telegraph Co. into the Murray automatic printing telegraph system. This was brought to London in 1901, and after further improvement was used by the British, German, Russian and other administrations. The Murray automatic system was combined with the Baudot multiplex by Murray, with the assistance of the British Post Office, between the years 1907 and 1912, the result being the Murray multiplex (a combined Automatic-Multiplex system). From this has developed the Western Union Multiplex, the Western Electric Multiplex and the Morkrum multiplex. All these American printing telegraphs, several thousands of which are now in use, embody the same permutation lever lock principle shown in the wooden model accompanying this description.

description: This remarkable type-printing telegraph is of the sliding type-bar class, but each bar has the whole alphabet on its printing face. The apparatus was constructed by the inventor, a schoolmaster by profession, purely as an experimental model, and has never been developed. Nevertheless, it worked perfectly at over 200 words per minute with type fixed by means of seccotine to type-bars made from umbrella ribs. The type-bars are supported between two toothed discs gearing with pinions on a motor shaft, which slowly revolves. Between the discs is a drum, which is stationary, and has a series of sloping grooves terminated by cam surfaces. Each type-bar has five setting pins friction-tight in the bar and arranged to be set by five magnets. The positioning of a type-bar depends upon the setting of its pins, which are spaced apart at distances, 1, 2, 4, 8 and 16 units, each unit being equal to the width of a single type. The bars are adjusted to the printing position by means of the setting pins engaging as the bar rotates with sliding grooves. In this way the required letter is at the printing point after the bar has travelled 180° from the setting point. The setting of the bar is therefore a very leisurely process, and in this respect alone the printer is unique. Each pin, after passing through a groove, is reset by a sloping cam surface on the stationary drum, while each type-bar has a small lug on its underside, which comes in contact with a sloping reset plate after passing the printing point. The working model is provided with a transmitting mechanism, which actuates the setting magnets by means of perforated tape. This tape had at first two rows of holes for advancing the paper, but one row was subsequently found more satisfactory. It was shown adjacent to the five-unit perforator shown adjacent to the instrument. Inv. 1923-671.

description: This receiving perforator, invented and patented by Mr. F. G. Creed about 1901, is used in conjunction with the Wheatstone automatic telegraph, and produces at the receiving station a perforated tape, which is a replica of the original prepared for transmission by means of the five-unit perforator shown adjacent to the instrument. slip passing through the Wheatstone transmitter at the sending station. The received slip may either be used for retransmission, or be passed through a Creed printer, which types the message in ordinary characters. At an intermediate transmitting office, it was formerly necessary to transcribe messages from the Morse tape and to re-perforate the signals by hand, if required for transmission over another Wheatstone circuit. By the Creed system, the perforated tape is automatically prepared by the received signals at high speed. A relay, fixed to the baseboard, carries a light arm, which moves from side to side according to the direction of the incoming current. At the end of the arm is an arrangement for opening and closing a small valve which controls the supply of compressed air—at about 30 lb. per sq. in.—to pistons. The direction of movement of the pistons determines whether a marking or a spacing hole shall be performed through the paper slip. In order to avoid tearing the paper, a mechanical contrivance arrests the movement of the paper feed wheel for about 1/300th of a second while the punch is perforating and being withdrawn from the tape. A later pattern of Creed receiving perforator, which works without air pressure, was introduced in 1921.

description: The messages for transmission are first punched in tape by means of this perforator, which translates the Roman letter-space signals of the written message into the five letters of the five-unit telegraph alphabet. The perforator includes a typewriter keyboard and a punch-block with five punches and an electro-magnetic, the armature of which feeds the tape forward one letter space on its back stroke. On the right may be seen the lever for pulling the tape back letter by letter when a correction is necessary. The correction is made by striking the letter-shift key (caps), which punches five holes in a letter space, and so blots out all other permutations which have been previously punched. At the other end of the line this signal leaves the printer unaffected, its function being to shift the action of the printer from figures to letters. The signal may be repeated half a dozen times so as to blot out a whole word, and there will be no trace of the error in the printed message.
interpretation: This perforator translates Roman letter-space signals of written messages into the five letters of the five-unit telegraph alphabet. description:
Lent by The Institution of Electrical Engineers. The perforated tape, containing a batch of three or four messages, having been prepared, the next step is automatic transmission, that is to say, collection of the space signals and transmission as time signals. There are two well-known methods of accomplishing this. The first is the direct method, in which metallic brushes make electrical contact through the holes of the paper tape. In the second, or indirect, method, the signals are transmitted by the intervention of a number of small levers and rods controlled by the tape. This method, which is similar in principle to the Jacquard loom, was first used in the Wheatstone automatic transmitter, and experience has shown it to be the best. It is used in the present case.
The name of the instrument is derived from the fact that the slip perforations are in a single row. The transmitter automatically sends out a train of five currents impulse of a time, corresponding to one letter or character, with distinct pauses between each train.
With regard to any one train, if there is no current perforation in the corresponding five centre hole length of slip, the five current impulses are all negative, actually forming one continuous negative current. If, however, one or more perforations occur, the corresponding current impulses to line are positive in direction and the remainder of the five are negative.
A diagram placed beside the instrument shows the alphabet employed and (Figs. 2 and 3) the resulting currents to line produced by the passage of slip perforated with the word "and."

description: At the receiving station, the signals operate a polarised relay, in the local circuit of which is connected an electro-magnetic perforator. This consists essentially of a punching and a spacing magnet operated through contacts closed alternately by a vibrating reed. The speed of the latter is governed by a relay, so that it is kept in unison with the reed of a phonic-wheel which is incorporated in the transmitter. The receiving perforator produces a facsimile of the transmitting tape, which is then available for retransmission or for printing.

description: If the tape is not required for retransmission, the tape signals have to be translated into Roman signals and printed. The essential features of the Murray printer have been described in the label which accompanied the original models. The tape is fed along letter by letter (five units at a time) by a star-wheel carried on a shuttle, which is kept reciprocating by means of a cam. Each reciprocation rotates the star-wheel one letter space. The shuttle carries a die-plate coinciding with the circumference of the star-wheel and having five holes corresponding with the message holes in the tape. Five rods, fixed in the ends of five slotted combs, are free to enter the five holes in the die-plate if they are not obstructed by the paper tape which passes between the rods and the plate. On its inward stroke the shuttle with its die-plate presses the tape against the ends of the rods and those that are opposite holes in the tape pass through into the die-plate. By this means one particular group of slots in the combs, and only one out of 56, is brought into alignment so that a cross-bar can drop into it and cause a letter to print. From the point of view of the theory of machines, the combs form a complicated series of 56 permutation locks. The 56 cross-bars are the bolts or latches, and the universal bar which is really a universal key. The locks are continually being closed in different ways by the tape, and the universal key is continually opening the locks. This intricate system of keys and locks is inevitable in all cases where complex control is needed. Amongst other instances it is used in systems of railroad interlocking gear, and although there is no outward resemblance between the Murray and the Baudot telegraph systems, the principle of the permutation locks is the same in both cases, and indeed in all high-speed printing telegraph systems.

description: This instrument, like the Creed receiving perforator, is designed to reproduce perforated Wheatstone slips from the action set up by the incoming line currents. The apparatus is operated electrically and does not require a supply of compressed air. On the spindle of an electric motor, a disc, carrying cams on its front surface, is rotated. These cams in revolving pass over small rollers attached to the back portions of the marking and spacing punches. Between the back and front of each punch is a small gap, which is filled up by a bell-crank lever when the punch is required to perforate a hole in the paper. The position of each bell-crank lever is governed by the action of one of the two side electro-magnets, one being energised by positive and the other by negative condenser impulses. In each case, the attraction of the armature of the electro-magnet turns the corresponding bell-crank lever—to which it is attached by a thin brass strip—into a position to fill the gap. The appropriate cam on the revolving disc then forces the punch through the paper. At the end of the stroke, the heel of the bell-crank lever is brought into contact with a small pin, which turns it aside so that the punch does not again perforate the paper until the electro-magnet has been re-energised.
interpretation: This instrument is designed to reproduce perforated Wheatstone slips from the action set up by the incoming line currents. The apparatus is operated electrically and does not require a supply of compressed air.

description: This instrument was invented by Mr. H. H. Harrison, and is a good example of modern development in printing telegraph construction. The selecting mechanism is of the permutation disc pattern, and the type-wheel shaft is continuously rotated as in Hughes and Baudot printers. An original and effective method of shifting the type-wheel from the letter to the figure group is one of the principal features of the apparatus. The distributor is of the start-stop type, in which both the transmitting and receiving brush arms are automatically started and stopped by the current. The adjacent keyboard transmitter forms the sending portion of the equipment.

description: This modern apparatus is the sending portion of the Harrison type-printing system. The depression of a key selects the combination of positive and negative currents required to signal the desired symbol, and also causes an unlocking current to pass through the start magnets at both stations. This releases the brush arms, which are then carried round by the motor shafts to which they are frictionally coupled. The brushes sweep over corresponding segments of the distributor at both ends of the line, and the order of the marking and spacing currents determines the character to be printed at the receiving station.

description: This apparatus was recently invented by S. R. Smith, Esq., and is designed to store up a number of signals in readiness for transmission over a circuit where the sending instrument operates at definite time intervals. In such cases, the telegraphist, working with a storage transmitter, has to observe the pauses, but if he works the key-board direct to line, has to observe any desired speed, the symbols being stored and transmitted in turn. The depression of a key lever causes metal pins to project from one of a series of radial lines of holes in a disc, the projections being in accordance with the symbol selected. The disc is constantly revolving, and each line of pins is in turn brought into connection with contact springs controlling a relay which sends the selected currents to line. After performing this function, the pins are restored to normal in readiness for further selection.

description: This cable consists of a single copper wire, thickly covered with gutta-percha, but without external armour. Lead weights were attached at intervals to keep the cable on the bed of the sea. Messages were transmitted from shore to shore, but the action of the tides near the coast soon destroyed the insulating material and rendered the cable useless. The owners did not expect permanent success from this first trial, which was regarded as an experimental test of the practicability of the enterprise. This having been established, armoured cable was laid between the same points in 1851.

description: These are specimens of the early submarine cables which were laid across the Atlantic Ocean. The first was successfully completed in August, 1858, but broke down after a few weeks' existence. It was ascertained later that the high power used to transmit the signals had permanently injured the gutta-percha insulation of the conductor. The instrument on which the first words from Newfoundland were received at Valentia is shown in another part of this case (see Henley’s galvanometer, Cat. No. 59). The next attempt to lay an Atlantic cable was made in 1865, when the “Great Eastern,” at that time the largest commercial ship afloat, was specially fitted with cable tanks for the enterprise. In spite of every care, however, breakages during the process of laying the cable were so numerous that the project had to be abandoned. A new cable was manufactured in 1866, and this was successfully laid. The cable of the previous year was then grappled, after 30 attempts, and the end was brought to the surface from a depth of over two miles. New cable was provided to complete the work, which was carried to a satisfactory termination. Thus two cables became available for communication between this country and America. The specimens shown are:— ATLANTIC CABLE, 1858. No. 1.—Main cable. No. 2.—Shore end. Length, 2,174 nautical miles. ATLANTIC CABLE, 1865. No. 1.—Main cable. No. 2.—Shore end. Length, 2,300 nautical miles. ATLANTIC CABLE, 1866. No. 1.—Main cable. No. 2.—Shore end. Length, 1,852 nautical miles. ATLANTIC CABLE, 1865. Recovered from a depth of 1,950 fathoms after 13 months’ submersion. MODEL GRAPNEL. Model of grapnel used in recovery of 1865 cable. GRAPNEL ROPE. Used in recovery of 1865 cable.

description: The siphon recorder was patented by Lord Kelvin (then Sir William Thomson) in 1867. The instrument shown was one of the original six sent out in 1870 by the Eastern Telegraph Co. It was worked in Egypt, on the main line to India, until 1882, and later on less important lines. A few of the parts are missing. The essential portions of the apparatus are powerful magnets terminated in soft iron pole pieces with a narrow gap between them. Within the gap, and consequently lying in a strong magnetic field, a thin rectangular coil of very fine silk covered copper wire is lightly suspended. The feeble current received from a long submarine cable passes through the coil and causes it to turn to the right or left according to the direction of the current. These movements are conveyed to a delicate glass siphon, one end of which dips into an inkwell, while the other end lies over a paper tape on which a wavy line, corresponding to the deflections, is traced. The instrument was first made in it simplest form, except that a method of reducing the friction of the glass on the paper, by causing the siphon to be vibrated by a trembler bell arrangement, has rendered the instrument still more sensitive to weak currents and enables long cables to be worked at a somewhat higher speed.

description:
The original form of curb sender for diminishing the effect of inductive retardation in long-submarine cables was designed by Lord Kelvin in 1858. The instrument here shown, which is due to Messrs. Taylor, Dearlove and Brown, is a special form of curb sender for correctly retransmitting the signals received on a relay, and was patented by Mr. S. G. Brown, F.R.S., in 1899. The relay mentioned was designed to overcome the difficulty of securing sufficiently good electrical contact under the slight pressure obtainable from an instrument actuated by weak arrival currents at the end of a long cable. The point of a contact arm (representing the siphon in the ordinary form of recorder) was caused to traverse the cylindrical surface of a rapidly rotating drum. This surface was divided into two parallel halves by a short insulating space on which the arm normally rested, so that two separate conducting surfaces were provided, with either of which the arm would make contact in its excursions from the central position.
The special form of curb sender here shown is designed to secure the correct retransmission of any given number of consecutive elements of a letter which are of the same sign, but which signals are received at the end of a long cable; the relay arm will not return to its zero position between consecutive elements of the same sign, but will remain on the respective contact surface during the whole time occupied by such consecutive elements.
The instrument consists of two cams, the form of which regulates the component of the curb-fed signal, one cam being for the dot element and the other for the dash. These cams, by means of clutches controlled by the relay, are mechanically rotated by clockwork, the speed of rotation being approximately adjusted to the rate of transmission of a single element; so that the requisite number of consecutive elements is transmitted, corresponding to the duration of contact of the relay arm with the side controlling that particular element.
By a modification of the apparatus the message, instead of being immediately retransmitted, can be punched on a slip which can be inserted in an automatic transmitter.

description: This relay, designed by S. G. Brown, Esq., F.R.S., receives signals attenuated after transmission through a long submarine cable, and restores them to their original strength before retransmission through a second cable. The signal currents pass through a coil delicately suspended in a strong magnetic field. The automatic transmitter (i.e. a battery reverser operated by perforated tape) at the distant end of the cable causes the received currents to traverse the coil in one direction for a Morse dot and in the opposite direction for a Morse dot. Thus the coil makes a small angular movement either to right or left, and a contact-making pointer to which it is harnessed is deflected on to one or other of two silver discs and thereby closes the local circuit of the dot or dash retransmitting relay. A feature of this instrument is the method of eliminating friction between the pointer and the adjacent silver contacts by rotating the latter at a moderate speed through the medium of a small electric motor. Without this device the minute forces of the signal currents would not suffice to move the pointer.

description: This is a portion of the submarine cable laid between New York and the Azores for the Western Union Telegraph Co. It is continuously loaded with a new magnetic alloy, developed by the Western Electric Co., which strengthens the magnetic field 2,000 times. It represents the first radical change in submarine cable construction for more than 50 years. In contrast to the other electrical industries, the development of submarine cables has been slow and conservative, owing to the great expense involved in any large-scale experiments. In 1887 the late Oliver Heaviside investigated the problems raised by the large capacity of long cables, and showed how the effects could be counteracted by the insertion of loading coils. In 1899 the suggestion was taken up by Pupin, who gave practical details for this method, but it was not until 1906 that the first Pupinised underwater cable was laid, in Lake Constance. In 1902 it was proposed by Krarup for loading the cable continuously by wrapping an iron wire round the copper conductor, but the losses in ordinary iron were found to offset the gains, so that the method was never extensively used, while it was found impossible to surmount the mechanical difficulties of jointing, &c., for the use of Pupin coils in deep-sea cables. The discovery of “Permalloy,” a heat-treated nickel-iron alloy having a permeability 2,000 as great as ordinary iron, has made it possible to revert to continuous loading. The alloy is made in the form of tape, 6/100ths in. thick, and is wound immediately over the copper core. An experimental length of 120 miles of cable loaded in this manner was submerged to a depth of 2½ miles at Bermuda on the 13th October, 1923, and this having proved entirely satisfactory, the full 2,300 miles necessary for an Atlantic cable were manufactured forthwith. The counteraction of capacity effect given by the new form of loading has resulted in a manifold increase in the traffic capacity, while it is stated that there is no limit to the length of cable which could now be operated without intermediate relays. The possibilities in the Pacific Ocean are greater than in the Atlantic, as fewer facilities exist there already. Inv.

description: Arresters are designed to carry away the great rush of current that results from a lightning flash near a line, and so prevent injury to the operators or the instruments. The charge in a line from lightning is of such potential that it will leap air gaps or other resistances that are quite impassable to the battery current, and it is upon this difference that the action of most arresters relies. The vacuum arrester was invented by Mr. C. F. Varley in 1847, although not patented till 1861, and is for the protection of an underground line connected with an overhead one. From the line, wire is led to platinum terminals fixed into a glass globe, in which is also a wire connected to the earth. The line terminals end in points close to the earth wire, and by exhausting the air from the globe the resistance of the gap is so reduced as to leave a ready path for high-tension electricity. (a) This form of arrester was brought out by Mr. Varley about 1856, and is designed for protecting six line wires. It consists of six metal points, each one connected to a line wire, and fixed radially in close proximity to a ring connected to earth; the whole is covered with a glass bell-jar (missing), under which probably contained a chemical that absorbed the gas in the bell, and the other mercury, which acted as a barometer column. (b) This is a smaller and modern form of the vacuum arrester (a), and is intended for a single line.

description: Made by Messrs. J. W. Albert. Lent by The Institution of Electrical Engineers. 1863 This instrument, made in 1863, was invented by Philipp Reis of Frankfurt for the transmission and reception by electrical means of all kinds of sounds. Since it definitely succeeded in this, the invention is generally held to be the first electric telephone. / From his published work it appears that Reis fully understood the fundamental principles involved in the electrical transmission and reception of sounds, and although his apparatus was less perfect than that of later inventors, it was undoubtedly capable of transmitting articulate speech as well as musical sounds. / Reis named his apparatus the “Telephon.” He probably designed ten distinct forms of transmitter and four forms of receiver. The apparatus here shown embodies the final forms of each. The transmitter consists of a hollow cube of wood having a circular opening in the lid which is closed by an elastic membrane (pig's lesser intestine). Upon the centre of this membrane is glued a little plate of platinum, which is connected with one terminal by a thin metal strip. Upon the middle of the platinum plate rests a short platinum pencil fastened to the underside of an angular metal strip. At one end of this strip a platinum spike on the underside rests in a mercury cup while the other end rests upon a metal pillar connected with a second terminal. / On speaking into the mouthpiece of the instrument the membrane vibrates and produces loose-contact phenomena between the platinum plate and the pencil. That these were intended to give a following-contact and not a clean break seems likely from the inventor’s writings and from the design of his other transmitters, in all of which some form of following-contact is formed. / On the side of the resonating box a simple telegraph apparatus is placed for the purpose of supplementing the telephone communications. / The receiver consists of a resonating box on the top of which is placed a long solenoid wound on a wooden bobbin. Through the centre of this a steel knitting-needle is thrust. A hinged lid closes over the solenoid. / The changes in the magnetic state of the needle occasioned by the speech-varied current create vibrations which are communicated to the resonant box, the original sounds being reproduced with sufficient distinctness to be heard by anyone placing his ear to the box. (See “Philipp Reis,” by S. P. Thompson, 1883.) Inv. 1923-273.

description: This form of magnetic telephone, patented by Prof. Alexander Graham Bell in 1876, was one of the earliest to be brought into practical use. The instrument consists of a permanent horse-shoe magnet, having short coils mounted upon its poles, while in front of the coils is a thin iron disc or diaphragm carried by a block of wood, through which there is a hole communicating with an external mouth or ear-piece. The coils are joined in series, and connected by a line wire with those of a similar instrument, the circuit being completed by connecting one terminal at each end with the earth. Speech uttered into the mouth-piece of one of the instruments sets the diaphragm into a state of vibration, and its movements produce variations of the number of lines of magnetic force passing through the coils. Alternating currents, corresponding to the pitch, amplitude and timbre of the sound, are consequently induced, and are transmitted to the second instrument. On passing through the coils of the latter, these currents, by producing changes in the magnetisation, cause variations of the force with which the diaphragm is attracted. This is consequently made to repeat the movements of the first diaphragm, and the original sounds are reproduced. Each instrument is used alternately as a transmitting and as a receiver to reproduce the sounds. In modern telephony distinct instruments are employed for transmitting and receiving. The receivers generally used are similar in principle to those shown, but considerably modified in design; modern transmitters, however, are altogether different, phenomena of loose-contact being employed to impress audio-frequency modulations on the current from a battery.

In two of the examples shown the spring acts through a pivoted lever, the contacts being, in one case, between three small blocks of pinewood charcoal and in the other between a piece of coke and a steel rod. In the third example, the contacts are between carbon pellets contained on a glass tube and acted on directly by a helical spring.
(3) Microphone consisting of two weighted carbon rods suspended by paper strips so that they lie horizontally, each in contact with two vertical carbon rods. There are thus four contacts in series. The microphone is mounted on a pinewood diaphragm.
(4) Granular microphones in which a very large number of contacts are obtained by passing the current through a tube containing a granulated substance. The substances most often used by Prof. Hughes were zinc and silver filings. Three examples are shown, the granules being contained in a quill, a glass tube and a hollow bamboo. This type of microphone was developed by Prof. Hughes without knowledge of the previous work of Edison.
Several types of microphones were used for detecting wireless signals. (See “Electrical Communication,” Part II, Cat. No. 1.) Inv. 1922-142-231.

description: This is an early example of the application of Hughes's carbon pencil microphone, with multiple contact points, to purposes of telephone transmission. It was patented by Mr. L. J. Crossley in 1879. The instrument was adopted as the standard transmitter by the Post Office, and was also largely used by telephone companies. Early in 1879, a Crossley transmitter was used for the transmission of a service from the Square Congregational Chapel, Halifax, to Manchester, over a route of 36 miles. The singing, organ music and sermon were distinctly heard. As one of the first successful experiments in distance telephony, it was regarded as a remarkable achievement. Four pencils of carbon, smaller in diameter at the ends than in the central area, and arranged approximately in the form of a rectangle and fit loosely into holes, drilled in carbon blocks, fixed to a thin deal diaphragm. Connecting wires are taken from two opposite corners of the rectangle, so that the eight variable resistance contacts are arranged four in series, in two parallel circuits.

description:
This interesting transmitter was found, with other portions of a disused telephone, fixed to a wall of a house in Cambridge. The mouth-piece was in communication with the hollow wooden block, air pressure variations due to speech affecting equally two non-metallic membranes placed opposite each other and on either side of the orifice.
The membranes have metal centre-pieces, and their motion induces speech currents in the neighbouring magnet-windings. The instrument in fact comprises two receivers of the Stanhope type used inversely, as the early Bell instruments were used, to act as transmitters.
The receiver used in conjunction with this transmitter was also of the Stanhope or membrane pattern.

This transmitter was patented by Mr. Campbell Swinton in 1884. A diaphragm is dispensed with, and the vibrations of the voice act upon a number of wooden tongues, which are freely suspended at one end and carry carbon contacts at the other.
In the example shown six tongues are suspended by tapes from a cross-member. At their lower ends strips of carbon are attached, and these press lightly on small carbon blocks, cylindrical in shape, which are placed at right angles to the strips. Each strip makes electrical contact with two adjacent carbon blocks, and alternate blocks throughout the length of the transmitter are connected with a brass which carries a terminal strip.
The arrangement is such that there are 12 variable contacts, arranged two in series in six parallel circuits. The mechanism is mounted on a board hinged at the top so that its inclination to the vertical, and consequently the pressure of the contacts upon each other, may be adjusted.

description: This is one of the first subscribers' sets supplied by the Edison Telephone Co., which commenced operations in this country in 1879. The main features of the instrument, the carbon transmitter and electromotograph (see adjacent exhibit), were patented by Edison in 1877. The transmitter, used—the parent of all modern transmitters—consists essentially of a button of soft carbon, about 3/8 in. in diameter, placed between two brass discs. One of these discs has a small glass centre, against which presses a brass stud fixed to the sheet iron diaphragm. The two brass discs are connected with the terminals of the instrument. Speech into the mouth-piece causes the diaphragm to vibrate, and produces variations in the resistance of the button and corresponding variations in the current transmitted through the line. The receiver, or “electromotograph,” has a small chalk cylinder, which is kept moistened with potassium iodide, and which is rotated by a handle through worm gearing. A brass diaphragm carries at its centre a brass strip spring, holding a platinum contact piece, which presses lightly against the chalk cylinder, the spring being tangential to the cylinder. The amount of friction exerted on the platinum contact by the rotating cylinder varies with the current passing to it from the sender, and this causes the spring and diaphragm to vibrate. The vibrations are damped by an indiarubber pad, the pressure of which against the back of the spring may be adjusted by a screw. This receiver, although loud and clear, required too much attention, and was abandoned after the amalgamation of the Edison and Bell Companies in 1880. Within the box, on which the transmitter is fitted, is an induction coil with three windings, and the mechanism seen above the box is a relay for the bell. There are also two keys, one for ringing and the other for closing the local microphone circuit. When the ringing key is up, the relay and the “tertiary” of the induction coil are connected in series between line and earth. Depressing the relay key breaks this connection and substitutes the battery between the line and earth. The microphone circuit is made up of the microphone, two cells of the battery, microphone key and primary of the induction coil. The tertiary coil acts as secondary for transmission and primary for receiving. Inv.

description: Patented in 1880. Owing to the very small electric currents developed in the magnetic telephone as arranged by Graham Bell (Inv. 1906–10), it could be used efficiently as a transmitter over comparatively short distances only. Transmitters were consequently introduced in which currents from batteries were utilised, and the acoustical effects were employed to produce variations of the resistances of the circuits. Undulating currents were thus obtained, which, by means of magnetic receivers, were made to reproduce the exciting sounds. At first the transmitter and its battery were placed in circuit with the line wire and the distant receiver, and as the variations in resistance produced in the transmitter were small compared with the total resistance, the changes in the current were correspondingly small. This difficulty was overcome by using an induction coil, the primary of which was in circuit with the transmitter and battery, while the secondary was connected with the line. T. A. Edison in 1877 constructed an instrument of this type, the action of which depended upon changes in the resistance of carbon with variations of pressure, while, in 1878, Prof. D. E. Hughes introduced his "microphone" (Cat. Nos. 100 and 101), which utilised the variation of the resistance of substances in loose contact placed in the neighbourhood of the sounds to be reproduced. Carbon was found to be the most suitable material, and many forms of carbon transmitters embodying the principle of Hughes's apparatus are now employed. The instruments shown are of a type which was used in the British Post Office, in which a carbon transmitter, patented by Mr. F. A. Gower in 1880, is employed. This consists of eight carbon pencils, supported between eight carbon blocks and one central block, all the blocks being recessed to receive loosely the reduced ends of the pencils. Four of the outside blocks are connected by means of a copper strip with one terminal of the battery, while the remaining four are connected, through the primary of an induction coil, with the other. The blocks are mounted upon a thin deal board, which constitutes the diaphragm and is enclosed in a wooden casing fitted with a porcelain mouth-piece.

description: A. B. Strowger, the inventor of the first successful automatic telephone exchange, filed his original application for a patent in America in 1889. The earliest public exchange worked on this system was opened at La Porte, Ind., in 1892. The instrument exhibited is an example of the early type of wall telephones arranged for connection to a Strowger automatic telephone exchange. A complex dialling switch was used with each instrument, and the case is left partially open to show the interior portion of this. In modern practice, the apparatus at the subscribers' premises is of a much more simple character. Situated at the base of the dialling switch are the coils of a magneto bell, the two gongs of which are on the front of the case. A magneto generator is fitted inside the box as hand-ringing was necessary with this instrument. In modern exchanges machine-ringing is general. The lower part of the case contained the primary cells required for the speaking circuit before the central battery system was adapted to automatic telephone transmission. A. B. Strowger was an undertaker in Kansas City, and frequently used the telephone for business purposes. This originated his desire to substitute machine operation for manual operation. Between the years 1892 and 1902 progress was slow, but with the adoption of new inventions and improvements the automatic telephone extended its influence in all parts of the world and many of the largest exchanges are now worked on the automatic principle. The first public automatic telephone exchange in this country was installed at Epsom in 1912. Other systems of automatic telephone exchanges are the Siemens, the Western Electric, &c.

description: The problem of linking up very large area by means of automatic telephone exchanges is naturally an extremely complex one. Means must be provided whereby a subscriber on any automatic exchange may connect himself with any subscriber on his own or any other exchange, and the connection must be made in such a manner as to make the most economical use of lines and automatic switches. Moreover, during the period of transition which must elapse before the whole system has been converted to automatic working, special apparatus must be provided to deal with calls between the existing manual exchanges and the new automatic exchanges. After a prolonged study of the problem, the British Post Office Authorities have decided that the system to be installed in the London Area shall be based on the well-known Step-by-Step system, with the addition of the important “Director” principle. The function of the Director is to receive and store the subscriber’s call in its original form, and to proceed to send it out into the exchange switching mechanism, translated into any trains of impulses which may be required by the existing lay-out of junction routes and switching centres. Having steered the call through, link by link, to the line of the required subscriber, the director disconnects itself from the line and becomes available for other calls. Another important feature of the system is the Coder Call Indicator. This switchboard is the connecting link between a subscriber on an automatic exchange and a subscriber served from a manual exchange. It is a fine example of engineering skill, permitting impulses received from the automatic subscriber to be translated by the Director to be reproduced in the manual exchange in the form of an illuminated display of the required number. description: Presented by H.M. Postmaster-General. 1886 This instrument, invented by Mr. D. Sinclair, represents the first attempt to provide an automatic telephone exchange in Great Britain. It was installed at Coatbridge, near Glasgow, in 1886, ten years before the first automatic exchange was set up in America. The apparatus consists of a step-by-step sender and a six-line switchboard with earth-return circuits. The step-by-step sender was employed at a central exchange to transmit currents to the automatic instrument which was placed in the branch exchange. This instrument was provided with a clockwork and electro-magnetic arrangement actuated by the incoming currents, which completed one of six circuits according to the position taken up by a rotating arm. The subscribers were connected in these circuits and a ringing current was afterwards sent out from the central exchange. Inv.

collection: THE TRANSMISSION OF PHOTOGRAPHS OVER LONG TELEPHONE LINES
object_name: THE TRANSMISSION OF PHOTOGRAPHS OVER LONG TELEPHONE LINES
description: An examination of these telephotographs will show the degree of technical excellence to which the transmission of pictures over long telephone lines has now been carried. The system, which has been worked out over a period of several years by the American Telephone and Telegraph Co. and the Western Electric Co., represents the association of numerous modern inventions, such as the thermionic tube and the carrier-current transmission system, with the fundamental device known as a photo-electric cell. The simplicity of the method is such that a positive transparency, prepared by any photographer, may be sent while still wet over lines practically of any length in a few minutes, and after photographic development of the usual sort it is ready for newspaper or other reproduction. A photographic film, which is a transparent positive of the picture to be transmitted, is rolled inside a transparent cylinder. The cylinder and film are rotated at uniform speed, and at the same time advanced axially by a lead screw mechanism. During rotation a very fine beam of light passes through the transparent film and impinges on a sensitive photo-electric cell, which is mounted inside the cylinder. The intensity of the light impinging on the cell varies in accordance with the density of the film and corresponding variations of current are produced in the cell. These variations are employed to modulate a "carrier" current having a frequency of 1,300 cycles per second. The carrier current is transmitted over the line and at the receiving end its varying amplitudes control a light valve (a sensitive shutter device), which determines the amount of light impinging on a sensitised film attached to a cylinder similar to that employed at the transmitting end and rotating in synchronism with it. In this way the light and shade of the original picture are reproduced, but the received picture will be a negative instead of a positive. The motion of the cylinders at the two ends is synchronized by means of tuning forks controlling a 400-cycle synchronizing current, which is transmitted over the same circuit as the picture currents, the separation of the two currents being effected by means of electric wave filters.
